review.title: Conversational Flow in Oxford-style Debates
review.abstract: Public debates are a common platform for presenting and juxtaposing diverging views on important issues. In this work we propose a methodology for tracking how ideas flow between participants throughout a debate. We use this approach in a case study of Oxford-style debates---a competitive format where the winner is determined by audience votes---and show how the outcome of a debate depends on aspects of conversational flow. In particular, we find that winners tend to make better use of a debate's interactive component than losers, by actively pursuing their opponents' points rather than promoting their own ideas over the course of the conversation.

metadata.title: Conversational Flow in Oxford-style Debates

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Public debates are a common platform for presenting and juxtaposing divergent viewpoints. Unlike monologues, in which speakers confine themselves to expressing their own beliefs, debates allow participants to interactively attack their opponents "points while defending their own. The resulting flow of ideas is a key feature of this discussion genre. In this work, we introduce a mathematical framework for characterizing debates with respect to the flow of conversation, which encompasses two main discussion strategies - promoting one's own points and attacking opponents" arguments - and tracks their relative use throughout the debate. By applying this methodology to an environment in which debate winners are known, we show that discussion-oriented flow patterns are predictable, which the debater is more likely to convince an audience. Case study: Oxford-style debates provide a framework that is particularly convenient for studying the impact of the flow of conversation. In this competitive debate format, two teams argue for or against an audience to take a stand.

sections.heading: 2 Debate Dataset: Intelligence Squared
sections.text: In this study, we use transcripts and results from the public debate series "Intelligence Squared Debates" (IQ2).2 These debates are recorded live and contain motions covering a variety of topics mitigated by for-1Other potential sources of confusion. Each debate consists of two opposing teams - one for the movement and one against - of two or three experts in each movement, along with a moderator. Each debate follows the other and consists of three rounds.

sections.heading: 4 Predictive Power
sections.text: We evaluate the predictive power of our products in a binary classification: we say whether they are for or against a specific target group. This is a challenging task for people who are at the end of every IQ2 debate.

sections.heading: 5 Further Related Work
sections.text: Previous work on the structure of conversation has suggested approaches to model dialogue actions (Samuel et al., 1998; Ritter et al., 2010; Ferschke et al., 2012) or unraveled intertwined conversations (Elsner and Charniak, 2010; Elsner et al., 2011) Other research has considered the problem of recognizing conversational traits such as the presence of disagreements (Allen et al., 2014; Wang and Cardie, 2014) or the likelihood of relationship disintegration (Niculae et al., 2015). At the participant level, several studies present approaches to identifying ideological attitudes (Somasundaran and Wiebe, 2010; Rosenthal and McKeown, 2015) based on traits based on participants "interactions (Thomas et al., 2006; Sridhar et al., 2015) or the elaboration of words and reasons that characterize an attitude (Monroe et al., 2008; Nguyen et al., 2014; and Hasan.).

sections.heading: 6 Limitations and Future Work
sections.text: This study opens several avenues for future research. It would be interesting to explore more complex representations of discussion points and discussion points, for example, using topic models or word embedding. Furthermore, it would be interesting to investigate the interplay between our conversation flow functions and relatively monological characteristics, which take into account the argumentative and rhetorical characteristics of each side separately. A clearer comparison and contrast of monological and interactive dynamics could lead to better conversation models. Such approaches could also help clarify some of the intuitions about conversations examined in this work, in particular that participation in dialogue has different strategic implications for self-promotion. Our focus in this paper is on capturing and understanding conversation flows. We therefore make some simplistic assumptions that can be refined in future conversations.
